topics.body:
"@Princess♠Molestia":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55aad4056368722ec0000201#post_55aad4056368722ec0000201
Basically they are saying that if people steal your art online it really isn't "Stealing" because your art isn't "Real".

And saying art thief is only when someone is stealing an actual painting/art piece. 

So basically if someone steals our art it isn't "Stealing" because our art isn't a physical object. Thus making our art not "Real".

topics.body:
Serious question: _Is reddit even a good place to advertise your work?_

I keep trying to submit some of my pony videos from my YouTube channel to various MLP subreddits, but I keep getting this stupid "you've posted too many links recently. try again in a hour." I do, and I keep waiting, but I keep getting the same stupid message every time.

Am I doing something wrong? Can someone please explain this?

topics.body:
"@Number1pegasus":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55aad4996368722e7c000360#post_55aad4996368722e7c000360
Well, to be fair, they might not be wrong. It's basically the same argument for pirating video games. It's not actually theft, since the "stolen" thing is still there, which clashes with the meaning of "theft". Of course, just because it's not technically theft doesn't make it automatically right. And to their credit, that's not what DA actually claims.

However, this isn't even the actual issue here. For the most part, this article is actually pretty okay and I can agree with large parts of it. One could argue that they talk too much about things that don't matter very much (like the definition of "art theft"), but nothing's really bad.

Except for one single thing. And that _is_ the actual issue.

They talk quite a bit about what you can do to protect yourself. Good idea. Like, how you can add a watermark, lowering the resolution, contacting the DA staff to report...

Oh wait. That one's missing.

Yeah, they talk quite a bit about how you can protect yourself from art theft (or whatever they call it) and what you can do when it happens. But no word on how DA itself can help you and I doubt that they just forgot that part.

Bottom line: Someone took your art on DA? Tough shit, you're completely on your own.
